item.desc: Entries in which the practitioner uses the term ‘ægritudo’ (sickness or grief) or a cognate term to describe a problem of the passions.

The terms to look out for are: ægritudo/egritudo (n: sickness, grief, affliction, melancholy); æger/eger (adj: sick, ill, unwell); ægreo/egreo, ægroto/egroto (vb: to be sick, ill, unwell); ægrotus/egrotus (adj: sick, ill, diseased). This takes resp.
Entries in which the practitioner explicitly records someone as being ‘afflicted’, where the problem is one of the passions.
The Latin ‘afflictus’ is sometimes used; this topic should be employed for that too. This takes resp.
Entries in which the practitioner explicitly records someone as being ‘amiss’, where the problem is one of the passions.
This takes resp.

For references to people who are suffering from bad dreams or are troubled with dreams; not for questions about the possible prophetic import of dreams, for which the topic dreams should be used instead.
Entries in which the brain is explicitly listed as the affected part and the disorder is mental rather than physical.
For people explicitly described as ‘crazed’ or ‘crazy’, or ‘crazed in the brain’ (note that this is often spelled with an s: ‘crasy’).

For explicit descriptions of people as despairing, suffering from despair, or ‘ready to despair’. For now, this topic should not be used where the question is discursive/descriptive and does not use the word itself.

For explicit descriptions of people as discontent or suffering from discontentment. For now, this topic should not be used where the question is discursive/descriptive and does not use the word itself.
Entries in which the term ‘disease’ (sometimes abbreviated to ‘diz’) is explicitly used in reference to mental disorder.
Takes resp.

For references to people as being ‘disquieted’, ‘disquieted in mind’ or whose mind is ‘not quiet’. Where the term ‘mind’ (or, in Latin, ‘animus’) is explicitly used, the topic mind should accompany this one.
For references to people as being ‘distempered’ or ‘out of temper’ in their mind or wits. The topics mind or wits should be combined with this one as necessary.
For people explicitly described as ‘distracted’ (in English) or ‘distractus/distracta’ (in Latin).

This topic should be used for entries that refer to someone being troubled with ‘evil thoughts’, ‘ill thoughts’, ‘bad cogitations’ or ‘cogitations’ (or ‘cogit’) where context implies that they are bad. If the phrase is ‘ill thoughts’ then illnessPassions should not be used in addition to this topic; if the full expression is ‘troubled in the mind with ill thoughts’ then the topics troubled, mind and evilThoughts should be supplied.

This topic covers references to ‘fancies’ (in Latin ‘fantasiæ’, or, more typically, ‘laborat fantasiis variis’). It also covers the description of people as ‘fantastic’. These seem to be more general delusions or hallucinations; references to auditory or visual hallucinations should be given the more specific topics hearingThings and seeingThings.

For explicit descriptions of people as fearful, suffering fear, or being afraid (as a problem, as opposed to the mention of it incidentally in entries for diseases of the body). Sometimes the expression used is ‘fearful and doubtful’; in this context the word ‘doubtful’ meant the same thing as ‘fearful’ and the topic fear covers both. For now, this topic should not be used where the question is discursive/descriptive and does not use the words listed above, though they can appear in English or in Latin (fear appears as ‘timor’).
Mental disturbances explicitly described as ‘fits’.
Where the problem is physical, the topic fits should be used.
For explicit references to people as ‘foolish’. Note that ‘foolish talk’ or ‘talking foolishly’ comes under the topic idleTalk.
For people explicitly described in English as ‘frantic’, ‘phrenetic’ or as suffering from ‘frenzy’, or in Latin as ‘phreneticus/phrenetica’, suffering from ‘phrenesis’, or ‘in phrenesin’.
For explicit descriptions of people as fretting. For now, this topic should not be used where the question is discursive/descriptive and does not use a form of the word ‘fret’.
For explicit descriptions of people as frighted. For now, this topic should not be used where the question is discursive/descriptive and does not use a form of the word ‘frighted’.

For explicit descriptions of people as grieving or suffering from grief. Note, however, that Napier seems to have asked querents (and possibly messengers) about any recent griefs suffered by his patients, which he presumably thought caused or contributed to their medical problems; this topic should not be supplied in those instances but should be reserved for entries in which the grief is clearly the problem about which the querent is consulting. For now, this topic should not be used where the question is discursive/descriptive and does not use the word itself.

Entries in which the head is explicitly listed as the affected part but the disorder is mental rather than physical. (It is of course possible for the head to be affected in both senses at once, in which case both ‘head’ and ‘head (passions)’ will be listed as topics.)

Entries in which the head is explicitly listed as the affected part but the disorder is mental rather than physical. If the head is affected in both senses at once, both head and headPassions should be given as topics.
This covers any references to auditory hallucinations; most typically people are described as hearing voices.
A term used formulaically by Napier to denote what might now be termed ‘depression’.

For any mention of the heart in the context of a problem of the passions: examples include being ‘sick at heart’ (in which case this topic should be used alongside sicknessPassions) and being ‘heavy in heart’ (in which case this topic should be accompanied by heaviness). In absence of clear evidence as to whether a reference to the heart is referring to the passions or the body, it is probably safest to assume that the problem is physical — though a choice of topics can be offered.

For descriptions of people as heavy, heavy-hearted or heavy-minded, or ‘leaden’ (one entry uses the phrase ‘harte leden’), where the implication is clearly not physical weight. We may decide later that this topic should be further broken down according to what specifically, if anything, is described as heavy.
For references to people as ‘idle headed’. Note that ‘idle talk’ or ‘talking idly’ comes under the topic idleTalk.
References to talking idly, fondly or foolishly; talking too much or too little; descriptions of people talking to themselves. (We may later decide to separate these out.)
Problems of the passions explicitly designated by the term ‘illness’ or a description of the sufferer as ‘ill’.

This takes resp. Where the condition suffered is physical, the topic illness should be used instead. Where an entry refers to ‘ill thoughts’ this topic should not be used; there ‘ill’ is synonymous with ‘evil’ and so evilThoughts should be recorded instead.
References to people who ‘cannot understand’, or to similar problems of comprehension/understanding.
Descriptions of or references to people who are incontinent, where the problem is one of the passions.

This topic is for explicit references to jealousy or to people being jealous (in sufficiently extreme a form for it to count as a problem of the passions): it can be spelled ‘iealous’ or ‘gealous’, and the Latin is ‘zelotypia’.

Descriptions of or references to people laughing as a sign that they have a problem of the passions. The implication is presumably that they are laughing compulsively, inappropriately, or for no apparent reason.
‘Light-headed’ is a term frequently used by Napier to describe people not entirely in their right wits: its precise meaning (if it has one) is yet to be established.
Care should be taken with this term as it sometimes indicates a problem of the passions and sometimes indicates simple dizziness.

For people explicitly described as out of their minds. Those who are merely ‘troubled’ or ‘not well’ in their minds (or similar) should, however, be given the topic mind plus an appropriate topic such as troubled, illnessPassions, amissPassions, sicknessPassions etc., or failing these, unidentifiedPassions. Napier seems to use the word ‘animus’ for mind when writing in Latin.

This is for references to people having lost their senses (meaning mental faculties, not sight, hearing etc.), their senses being ‘gone’, being ‘bereaved’ of them, or being ‘senseless’. Where the reference is to a milder problem of the senses, the topic senses should be used instead in combination with afflictedPassions, amissPassions, diseasePassions, illnessPassions, notWellPassions, sicknessPassions or failing these, unidentifiedPassions.

For people explicitly described as out of, bereaved of, or having lost or lost the use of their wits. Those who are merely ‘troubled’ or ‘not well’ in their wits (or similar) should, however, be given the topic wits plus an appropriate topic such as troubled, illnessPassions, amissPassions, sicknessPassions etc., or failing these, unidentifiedPassions. Napier seems to use the word ‘mens’ for the wits when writing in Latin.
For people explicitly described as ‘lunatic’ (in English) or ‘lunaticus/lunatica’ (in Latin).
For people explicitly described as ‘mad’ or as suffering from ‘madness’. The Latin term ‘delirium’ (or the expression (‘laborat delirio’) appears to be an equivalent.

For explicit descriptions of people as melancholy, or suffering from melancholy or melancholia (this can occur in Greek); not for references to the humour melancholy as the cause of physical ailments. For now, this topic should not be used where the question is discursive/descriptive and does not use the word itself.
Descriptions of or references to people who have lost their memories or are forgetful.
Whether or not someone will recover from a disorder explicitly described as being of a mental nature.
For any question that refers to some problem with the mind. Napier seems to use the word ‘animus’ to mean mind when writing in Latin.
For explicit descriptions of people as mopish. For now, this topic should not be used where the question is discursive/descriptive and does not use the word itself.
Diseases of the passions explicitly designated by the Latin term ‘morbus’.
Takes resp.
Entries in which the patient is described as ‘not well’ or ‘never well’, and is suffering from a problem of the passions.
For people explicitly described as ‘raging’. The Latin term ‘furiosus/furiosa’ appears to be equivalent.
For people explicitly described as ‘raving’. The Latin term ‘insaniens’ appears to be equivalent.
For entries in which subjects are described as believing that God is angry with them, or has forsaken them, or does not exist; that prayers will do little good; etc.
Where the question consists of or includes a report of the effects of previous treatment for mental disorder.

For explicit descriptions of people as sad, or suffering from sadness. For now, this topic should not be used where the question is discursive/descriptive and/or does not use the word itself; in particular, note that ‘sorrow’ and ‘grief’ have their own topics.

For any question that refers to some problem with the senses (meaning mental faculties, not sight, hearing, touch, taste and smell). The exception is where the problem is the loss of senses (senselessness), in which case the topic lostSenses should be used instead.
Mental disorder explictly described as ‘sickness’.
Takes resp.
For references to people being unable to sleep, where the context is otherwise entirely passions-related.

For references to people screaming (typically spelled ‘skreaming’) or ‘skriking’, where the implication is a problem of the passions rather than an indication of the extremity of pain. Where a young child is the subject, we typically assume that ‘skriking’ is an indication of discomfort, and do not supply a topic for it.

This covers any references to visual hallucinations, to people who are ‘troubled with ill sights’ or suffer a ‘foolish vision’ (or, in one case to date, ‘black visions’). It also covers any more discursive references to seeing things.

For explicit descriptions of people as suffering from sorrow. For now, this topic should not be used where the question is discursive/descriptive and does not use the word itself. For now references in Latin to ‘dolor’ (when it does not mean physical pain) should be given this topic, though we may need to investigate whether that should be sorrow or grief or some other topic (or if they are the same thing).
For explicit descriptions of people as sottish. For now, this topic should not be used where the question is discursive/descriptive and does not use the word itself.
Loss of speech through non-physical causes.

The term ‘tempted by Satan’ almost always (and often explicitly) means ‘suicidal’, but some patients are described as being tempted to commit other sins such as murder. Thoughts of suicide were generally understood at the time as by definition of Satanic origin.

This topic covers any references to someone being ‘tempted’, ‘tempted in mind’, ‘tempted to make her/himself away’, ‘tempted to kill...’ (e.g. spouse, children); also any references to attempts to commit suicide or someone being suicidal
References to people being in a trance (where the word ‘trance’ itself is specifically used).
For references to people being troubled in mind or wits. The topics mind or wits should be combined with this one as necessary.

For explicit descriptions of people as ‘uncomfortable’ (the word here meaning inconsolable). For now, this topic should not be used where the question is discursive/descriptive and does not use the word itself.

For references to people as ‘weak in mind’ or ‘weakened in the wits’ or suffering ‘weakness in the head’ (where the implication is of a passions problem). The topics mind, wits, headPassions etc. should be added as appropriate.

For references to or descriptions of people weeping or crying, where the implication is that they are suffering from a problem of the passions (not for when the point is to illustrate the degree of physical pain they are suffering, or to show their level of distress over a physical ailment).
For any question that refers to some problem with the wits. Napier seems to use the word ‘mens’ to mean wits when writing in Latin.
Entries that clearly relate to a mental issue, although none is specified in the question section.

This should always be given evidence, specifying internal if the judgment provides direct evidence that the consultation was passions-related, or external if the evidence comes from some source outside the case itself. (In theory, inferred is also available for the situation in which the inference is based on another component of the entry, such as a treatment note or a urine note, but in practice it would be impossible to distinguish passions entries from medical entries based on this alone, and the assumption should be that such entries are medical unless there is direct evidence of a passions-related problem.) An individual should not be associated with both unspecifiedPassions and another passions topic; unspecifiedPassions is a fall-back topic for ensuring an entry is designated as concerning the passions. It should not be used for recording the common phenomenon that particular symptoms are mentioned in the judgment but not in the question. However, one person can be given both unspecifiedPassions and any medical (non-passions) topic.
Questions that are clearly psychological in nature but couched in terms that defy more precise definition.

This topic is for questions that are either incomprehensible (though clearly relating to the passions) or cannot reasonably be placed into one of our existing topics. It currently includes expressions such as ‘confused’, ‘perplexed’ and ‘suddenly taken’, each of which has appeared once to date.

This is the category for any entry in which the subject is suffering from an ‘anxiety and melancholy’ problem, but one that is not classifiable according to the available categories above (currently: despair, discontentment, fear, grief, heaviness, melancholy, mopish, sadness, sleeplessnessPassions and sorrow). This is where people described as having ‘taken thought’ currently go; also those who fret, are sottish, doubtful, suspicious, or who start(le) or take fright in their sleep. Note that ‘uncomfortable’ in this period probably means inconsolable. This category will be monitored and new topics created as appropriate, depending on what turns up. To make recategorising these later on easier it is helpful to record in a comment tag after cb:topic what the precise expression used is.
This topic is for explicit references to people as ‘wild’ or ‘wild headed’ (in the latter case, the topic headPassions should also be used).
Entries in which the practitioner uses the term ‘ægritudo’ (sickness or grief) or a cognate term to describe a physical ailment.

The terms to look out for are: ægritudo/egritudo (n: sickness, grief, affliction, melancholy); æger/eger (adj: sick, ill, unwell); ægreo/egreo, ægroto/egroto (vb: to be sick, ill, unwell); ægrotus/egrotus (adj: sick, ill, diseased). This takes resp.
Entries in which the practitioner explicitly records someone as being ‘afflicted’.
The Latin ‘afflictus’ is sometimes used and should be given this topic. This takes resp.
Entries in which the practitioner explicitly records someone as being ‘amiss’.
This takes resp.
Confined to bed through illness.
Napier’s usual phrase for this is that X ‘keepeth his/her bed’, though there are variations. Sometimes it is the only clue in the question that the consultation is medical.

Entries in which the practitioner explicitly records the issue as ‘disease’ (normally abbreviated by Forman as ‘diz’). The term covers a much wider range of ailments than ‘disease’ in the modern sense, including (for instance) toothache or a bad back. The vast majority of Forman’s medical entries fall into this category, suggesting that medical questions not so designated belonged to a different category in his mind. Napier uses this category much less frequently and tends to be more specific about the nature of medical problems.
This takes resp.
Entries in which the practitioner explicitly records that a person is ‘distempered’ or ‘out of temper’.
This also covers references in Latin such as ‘intemperamentum corporis’ or ‘distemperatio’. If the problem is of the passions, the topic distemperedPassions should be used instead.
Entries in which the practitioner uses the term ‘grief’ to describe a physical ailment.
If the problem is of the passions the topic griefPassions should be used instead, though see under that topic for an important caveat.
Entries in which the practitioner explicitly records that a person is ‘ill’.

This takes resp. Where the condition suffered is one of the passions, the topic illnessPassions should be used instead. Where an entry refers to someone as being ‘ill handled’, the sense of ‘ill’ is different and the topic given should be unidentifiedMedical instead.
Entries in which the practitioner explicitly records the issue as ‘infirmity’ or ‘infirmitas’.
This takes resp.
Latin for ‘disease’.

For entries in which this specific term is used generally (however declined), though not for ‘morbus gallicus’ (morbusGallicus) or ‘morbus caducus’ (fallingSickness), which should be given their own topics. This takes resp.
Entries in which the patient is described as ‘not well’ or ‘never well’.
Entries in which the terms ‘sickness’, ‘sick’, ‘sickly’, ‘sickened’ etc. are used.

This takes resp. It is not to be used where Napier employs the word ‘sickness’ to refer to menstruation, the falling sickness, or ‘the new sickness’ (newAgue). If the expression or term employed is anything other than ‘sick’ or ‘sickness‘, it is worth recording in a comment tag.
Questions about the advisability of undertaking treatment with a particular practitioner.
Where someone explicitly requests bloodletting.

More general queries about bloodletting and its advisability should be given the topic bloodletting. Note that where one person requests bloodletting for another, the person element in cb:topic should point to the person for whom the bloodletting is being requested, not the person requesting it.
Where someone explicitly requests a sigil.
Where someone explicitly requests treatment other than bloodletting or sigils, either in general or of a particular nature.

Note that where one person requests treatment for another, the person element in cb:topic should point to the person for whom treatment is being requested, not the person requesting it. Where sigils are sought, the topic requestingSigils should be used instead, and where the demand is for bloodletting, the topic requestingBloodletting should be used.
Explicit requests for medical recipes.

The presence of a recipe in an entry should not be taken as an indication that the patient requested it; this topic is strictly for questions that explicitly specify that the querent is asking for a recipe, and as such it is used only rarely.
Questions posed (usually by the practitioner) about how and/or when a patient should be treated; also interrogations put by the practitioner concerning treatments he has already administered.
Where the question consists of or includes a report of the effects of previous treatment.
Questions posed (in some cases by the practitioner) about the advisability of bloodletting as a treatment, or about the likely effects of bloodletting already carried out.

The topic should be specified only where the question is recorded explicitly in the entry, but that can be in the judgment as well as in the question section (within the judgment, questions are often indicated by beginning ‘Quærit...’). The topic can be recorded in either case; where the question occurs in the judgment (or among the untranscribed material more generally) it should be given an evidence value of internal. Where an entry specifies that a person wants to be let blood, or has asked to be let blood, then the topic requestingBloodletting should be used instead.
Whether or not the person being asked about is at death’s door.

This is for life or death questions specifically in a medical context. (If a similar question is asked outside of a medical context then the topic liveOrDie should be used instead.) The topic should be specified only where the question is recorded explicitly in the entry, but that can be in the judgment as well as in the question section (within the judgment, questions are often indicated by beginning ‘Quærit...'’). The topic can be recorded in either case; where the question occurs in the judgment (or among the untranscribed material more generally) it should be given an evidence value of internal.
Forman’s formulaic term for questions about whether the person suffering the ailment will recover or grow worse.
Takes resp.

Whether or not someone will recover from their ailment, not necessarily as a result of medical intervention. This is a distinct (though not always very clearly distinct) category from ‘life or death’ in that it is possible to carry an illness to the grave but to die of something else.
Formulaic term for enquiries about an ‘alteration’ in the patient’s condition.
Whether or not the patient’s condition can be cured.
Whether or not the patient has fully recovered from or been cured of a given ailment.
Forman’s formulaic term for questions about the progress of a given problem or its cure.
This takes resp.
Another of Forman’s formulaic terms. Definition not entirely clear, but seems to refer to someone’s general physical wellbeing.
This takes resp.
Questions about the progress of an explicitly medical problem or its cure.
This takes resp.
Cases where the querent has explicitly asked what has caused a medical disorder, as opposed to what to do about it.
Entries in which the querent is recorded as having asked for advice or counsel of a medical nature.

Note that this is for entries in which Napier explicitly records a statement such as ‘X sent for my counsell’, and where the word ‘counsel’ (or a synonym) is explicitly used. This is not intended as a catch-all topic for all medical questions; questions about the advisability or timing of particular treatment, for instance, should be given the topic treatment, and questions that are clearly medical but difficult to categorise should be given the topic unidentifiedMedical. Entries that use the word ‘counsel’ or a synonym but which are non-medical in nature, or not demonstrably medical, should be given the topic counsel instead.
Entries concerning people who have been poisoned, who fear they may have been poisoned, or who wish to know if they have been poisoned.
Requests for help in preventing someone from developing a particular illness.
Questions about the advisability for a person’s health of adhering to particular routines, undertaking particular activities, residing in certain places or eating certain foods.
This covers anything to do with regimen, diet, the non-naturals, airs, and so on.
Requests for Napier to pray for the patient(s) in question.
Physical injury or wound.

This is a medical problem with an identifiable, physical and external cause, to be used when a direct reference is made to the traumatic event; references to a wound, or wounding, should also be given a trauma topic. Cf. bruise, which is not always linked to a traumatic event, and which will therefore sometimes but by no means always be accompanied by trauma. This topic should be used where the problem is given as the traumatic event itself, whether that information comes from the question section or the judgment, but it should not be used where the traumatic event is proposed as a possible cause for some other medical problem. (The distinction is between a subject visiting Napier because she has fallen off a horse, and a subject visiting Napier because she has a sore neck, which she thinks she may have got from falling off a horse.) If the reference to the traumatic event is in the judgment, an evidence value of internal should be supplied. Note also, incidentally, that when Napier uses the term ‘broken’ he is usually referring to a skin complaint (as in ‘broken out’), not an injury (as in a broken leg), so unless there is evidence to the contrary the topic skin should be used rather than the topic trauma.
Questions that are clearly medical in nature but couched in terms that defy more precise definition.

This topic is for questions that are either incomprehensible (though clearly medical) or cannot reasonably be placed into one of our existing topics. It includes general terms for illness such as ‘querysh’ (queerish), ‘wamblie’, ‘ailed’, and ‘impediments’, each of which has appeared once to date. It also includes non-specific, non-descriptive ‘problem’ terms such as ‘vexed’ (as in ‘vexed with wind colic’) or ‘tormented’ (as in ‘tormented with a cough’) where they appear alone and without further detail from which to supply specific topics. It is helpful to record in a comment tag beside cb:topic the expression or term that unidentifiedMedical is standing for.
Entries that clearly relate to a medical issue, although none is specified in the question section.

This topic is used where we know (or think) that a medical question was asked about a subject, but where no other medical topic can be supplied. It should always be given evidence, specifying the reason for identifying the entry as medical: internal if the judgment contains medical material, inferred if the inference is based on another component of the entry (such as treatment notes or a urine note), or external if the source of information is outside the case itself. A judgment stating ‘It is of (planet) in (constellation)’ can be taken as indicating a medical entry; this formula is specifically associated with medical entries and is used by the astrologers to record which planet on the chart stands for the disease. Women asking about pregnancy sometimes send their urine, so where a subject is female and the presence of urine is the only indicator that an entry is medical, it is usually safest to specify a cert of medium. If an entry includes two or more subjects, it is possible (and not uncommon) for one of those subjects to have an explicit question (and associated topics), while others are given unspecifiedMedical. However, an individual should not be associated with both unspecifiedMedical and another medical topic; unspecifiedMedical is a fall-back topic for ensuring an entry is designated as medical. It should not be used for recording the common phenomenon that particular symptoms are mentioned in the judgment but not in the question. Note also that for the purposes of this topic, ‘passions’ do not count as ‘medical’. A person can be given both the topic unspecifiedMedical and any passions topic. For passions equivalent of this topic see unspecifiedPassions.
Ulcer or fistula of the eye.
To be used when the problem is described as a fistula or ulcer of the eye, as well as when the term ‘aegilops’ (or ‘aegylops’) is used.
Malarial fever (but see also ‘new ague’).

It seems that ‘ague’ was used in this period in particular for a malarial fever, characterised by successive periods of extreme cold and shivering, followed by very hot, with those periods lasting different lengths of time - hence quotidian, tertian, etc. So references to ‘hot ague’ and ‘cold ague’, ‘cold shivering ague’, tertian ague’ and so on, should all be given this topic (and not given the associated topic hot, cold, burning etc., though the type of ague should ideally be recorded in a comment tag after cb:topic in case we refine this encoding later on). The ‘new ague’, however, has its own topic, newAgue.
Sudden loss of sensation and motion.
Sometimes appears as ‘apoplexia’.

For use only when the word ‘asthma’ (usually spelled ‘asma’ or ‘astma’) appears, not for discursive lists of symptoms such as shortness of breath and the like, for which topics such as shortWinded will likely be more appropriate.

This is for uses of the term ‘cataract’, rather than for descriptions of problems that sound as though they were probably cataract (topics such as eyes and eyesight are likely more appropriate for discursive accounts of that sort).
Simultaneous, sudden and violent diarrhoea and vomiting.
Spasmodic abdominal pain.

Note that stoneColic and windColic are available as topics where the question specifies one of those forms of colic. This is specifically for questions in which neither the stone nor wind is specified as a cause.
Oedema (accumulation of watery fluid in any part of the body).
Epilepsy.
This sometimes appears as ‘epilepsia’ (in Latin or Greek), sometimes as the ‘falling sickness’, sometimes as ‘morbus caducus’ or ‘morbus comitialis’.
Used at the time to refer to a symptom (genital discharge) rather than a disease in its own right; frequently referred to as ‘running of the reins’.
This appears as ‘gonorrhoea’ (and variant spellings) in Latin and Greek, as well as ‘profluvium renum’ and ‘seminis profluvium’.

Usually the term ‘gout’ is used, though also look out for the word ‘podagra’. There is some debate about how closely the use of the word in the early modern period equates to its modern sense, though it clearly does refer to foot pain of some description.
A wasting disease typically affecting relatively young women of post-puberal age, sometimes retrospectively diagnosed as chlorosis.
Stomach disorder.

Sometimes given in Latin as ‘hypocondriaca passio’ or ‘hipocondriaca passio’, or in shorter form as ‘hypocond. pass.’. This begins as a physical problem then rises to the head to become a passions problem.
This umbrella topic should not be used in coding case files; if an entry includes a reference to jaundice of unspecified colour, the subtopic jaundice should be employed instead.
For entries that refer explicitly to black jaundice; where the reference is to jaundice more generally, the topic jaundice should be used.
For entries that refer explicitly to green jaundice; where the reference is to jaundice more generally, the topic jaundice should be used.

Specifically for entries in which no particular colour of jaundice is mentioned. Where the jaundice is described as black, green or yellow, one of the topics blackJaundice, greenJaundice or yellowJaundice should be used instead.
For entries that refer explicitly to yellow jaundice; where the reference is to jaundice more generally, the topic jaundice should be used.
This is usually spelled ‘megrym’ (or similarly) by Napier.
Syphilis, or venereal disease more generally.
Napier’s term (he usually calls it ‘the new ague’) for an epidemic that appears to have broken out in Buckinghamshire in late 1598. It is unclear precisely what it was.

This is variously specified as ‘the new ague’, ‘the new disease’ and ‘the new sickness’; it should be given this topic and not ague, disease or sickness, unless one of those terms is specified separately — as in ‘disease ... the new disease’, or ‘ague ... the new sickness’.
Bubonic plague.
Afflicted by a sudden infirmity attributed to the malign influence of a planet.
Any ailment characterised by pock-marks, often retrospectively diagnosed as either smallpox or venereal disease.
Purpura (eruption of purple spots on the skin).
Tuberculosis of the lymph nodes in the neck. Often referred to as ‘Queen’s/King’s evil’ as it was supposedly curable by the touch of the monarch.
Suppurative tonsilitis.
Swelling of the throat. The terms ‘squinsy’ and ‘quinsy’ appear to be interchangeable, and the Latin ‘angina’ also seems to refer to the same thing.
For references to stone as a problem (not to its use to mean a testicle), excluding references to ‘stone colic’, which should be recorded using the topic stoneColic.
Sometimes referred to by Napier as ‘strangullion’.
For references to people who suffer strains or who overstrain themselves.
For references to people as having been ‘struck’, ‘stroken’, ‘stroken suddenly’, or similar.
An excess of one of the four bodily humours, frequently posited by Napier as the cause of a particular ailment.

For entries in which someone is described as having taken a cold; those entries in which someone is simply described as ‘cold’, or feeling some part of the body to be cold, the topic cold is to be used instead.
For entries in which someone is explicitly described as having a tympany, or fearing or suspecting a tympany.
Vaginal discharge.
Usually the term ‘whites’ itself is used, though references to ‘profluvium alborum’ can also be found.

Entries in which the head is explicitly listed as the affected part and the disorder is physical, not mental. Where the problem is mental the topic headPassions should be used instead. If the head is affected in both senses at once, both topics should be recorded.

Entries in which the brain is explicitly listed as the affected part but the disorder is physical, not mental. Where the problem is mental the topic brainPassions should be used instead. If the brain is affected in both senses at once, both topics should be recorded.
Anything covering problems with this part of the body, including references to the neck.

To be used where Napier indicates a problem with the eyes, even if we suspect that the problem is with eyesight. That is, if Napier writes that someone has bad eyes, then the topic is eyes; if he writes that they have poor sight, the topic is eyesight; if he writes that they cannot see out of their eyes, we should use both topics, eyes and eyesight.

Including parts of the face not covered by their own more specific topics, such as cheeks and forehead. On the other hand nose, for instance, has its own topic. Napier sometimes describes people as having ‘saucy’ or ‘sawcy’ faces, which is a reference to ‘saucefleme’, a swelling of the face; this should be therefore be encoded as face and swelling. (For more on this see respiratoryPhlegm.)

To be used where Napier indicates a problem with the ears, even if we suspect that the problem is with hearing. That is, if Napier writes that someone has bad ears, then the topic is ears; if he writes that they have poor hearing, the topic is hearing; if he writes that their ears are so bad that they cannot hear, we should use both topics, ears and hearing.
Usually referred to in the records as ‘fundament’.
Internal organs generally: not necessarily limited to intestines.
Specifically mammaries; if the word ‘breast’ is used to mean the chest, then the topic chest should be employed instead.
For references to ‘chest’ and to ‘breast’ (singular) used to mean the chest (cf. breasts).
Including the terms ‘cods’, ‘stones’, ‘yard’, ‘vulva’. For ‘share’ and ‘reins’ see groin.

Usually ‘share’, though on one occasion the term ‘reins’ has been used to mean groin. (Care is to be taken with the word ‘reins’: more typically it occurs in expressions such as ‘the running of the reins’ (gonorrhoea) or ‘the reins of the back’ (reinsOfTheBack), and it may mean kidneys, though Napier himself seems to use it in that sense rarely if ever.) This topic excludes terms such as ‘yard’ and ‘vulva’, which count as genitalia.
Usually referred to at the time as ‘reins’.

Napier actually typically uses the word ‘kidneys’, except in the phrases ‘reins of the back’ and ‘running of the reins’, both of which have their own topics. In one instance he clearly uses the word ‘reins’ to refer to the groin. In short, care is needed when dealing with the term ‘reins’.
The precise meaning of this term is unclear, but it does seem to be distinct from ‘reins’ in the sense of ‘kidneys’.

We are using a topic specifically for this expression pending finding out what it actually means. The word ‘reins’ in this sense seems to be distinct from its use to mean kidneys or groin, and this seems to be unconnected to the expression ‘the running of the reins’ (gonorrhoea).
The term ‘milt’ is sometimes used; it means the same thing as ‘spleen’.
Specifically for entries in which the term ‘belly’ is used (stomach is a separate topic).
Specifically for entries in which the term ‘stomach’ is used (belly is a separate topic).
Usually referred to in entries as ‘body’.
Usually referred to as ‘mother’ or ‘matrix’.
To be used where the hands are referred to explicitly, or for the term ‘chiragra’, which indicates a pain in the hand (in that instance the topic pain should also be used).
To be used where a question section includes the general term ‘limbs’; where a question specifies a particular limb or limbs, the appropriate topic(s) should be used: legs and/or arms.
Meaning hipbone.
Entries in which patients are described as being afflicted ‘everywhere’, ‘all over’, ‘in all parts’, etc.
Used so far a couple of times for people being pined or consumed in the flesh.

Either general skin problems, or in combination with a particular part or parts of the body. It is used both for explicit mentions of the skin and for references to problems such as ‘pimpling’ or morphew (typically ‘morphue’) that affect the skin. References to people being ‘broken’ in particular parts of the body are usually references to skin complaints, and this topic should be used rather than trauma unless there is additional evidence that the problem described is the breaking of a bone.
Questions around the feeding of a baby, such as whether it is advisable for a mother, or a particular nurse, to suckle the child, or whether an illness is as a result of that feeding
Napier typically uses the terms ‘suckle’ or ‘suck’.
Questions about medical problems suffered by women during the course of childbirth.
This is to be distinguished from the non-medical topic childbirth, which is for questions about a future childbirth.
Questions about stopped, excessive, irregular or painful menstrual periods.
Questions about excessive, irregular or painful menstrual periods.
For all problems relating to menstruation except entire lack, which goes under noCourses; this covers period pain, menstruating too much or too little, or variably; it includes ‘the reds’.
For complaints that menstruation has stopped.
For consultations concerning recent or repeated miscarriages, or requests for assistance preventing miscarriage. Note that Napier uses the term ‘abortion’ (or ‘obortion’).

This is for general references to swelling or to parts of the body being swollen. Where a question is asked about a ‘tympany’, the topics swelling and belly should be recorded; where a question is asked about ‘mumps’ or ‘mumphes’, the topics swelling and throatMouth should be recorded (as the term referred to a swelling of the neck or throat).

For when parts of the body are described as hard (for instance the belly). This is not to be confused with references to ‘hardness’ that concern the bowels (cf. looseness), which are more likely (depending on specific details) to come under the topic costive.
Including congealed blood.
Note that someone who is hot and cold by turns should be given the topic hotAndCold.
Though where the implication is that the problem is with the mind, the passions topic speechlessPassions should be used.
Anything from faltering speech to an inability to speak.

This is for problems with speech that are not ascribed to the mind and that fall short of outright speechlessness: faltering in one’s speech, for instance. Where the problem pertains to the passions, idleTalk is more likely to be appropriate.
This is specifically retention of faeces; inability to urinate is noUrine.

The term ‘flux’ itself is found numerous times within Napier’s casebooks; pending a proper investigation into early modern terminology for diarrhoea, we are following Franciscus Junius’s Etymologicum Anglicanum in translating ‘profluvium alvi’ as ‘flux’.
Of the bowels; also expressed as ‘loose bodied’. Note that although the term ‘hard’ is sometimes used as a description in the context of bowels, the topic hardness is not the opposite of this.
Specifically and solely for references to voiding phlegm; anything to do with the stomach or vomiting goes under nauseaPhlegm, and plain, ordinary phlegm goes under respiratoryPhlegm.

Sometimes literally ‘dizziness’ (or ‘dyssines’ or whatever), often ‘giddiness’, and sometimes ‘light headed’. It is worth bearing in mind, though, that ‘light headed’ is sometimes a passions problem (see lightheadedPassions), so attention to context is important. Also ‘swimming in his/her head’.
Including e.g. ‘ready to swound’ as well as ‘faint’. Actually swooning or fainting falls under swooning.
Specifically for uses of the word ‘feeble’.
For subjects who have actually swooned/fainted; those who are simply ‘ready to swound’ or who are ‘faint’ should be given the topic faintness.
For entries that specifically use the term ‘vertigo’, in full or abbreviated (including as declined in Latin passages).
Specifically for uses of the words ‘weak’ or ‘weakness’.
Loss of appetite or disturbed appetite: people being described as having a ‘weak stomach’ or who ‘cannot relish’ food, who refuse their food, can eat but little, and so on.
Anything from bloodshot eyes to complete blindness.
For bloodshot eyes.
As in ‘dimness of sight’ and the like; blindness is given the topic sightlessness.
Whether full blindness or temporary loss of vision.
Descriptions of eyes as specifically red (the topic eyes should be used as well as this one if the word ‘eyes’ is employed in the entry).
Specifically for eyes that have water, or are running.
Temperature/humoral; cf. aCold, for the named illness.
For references to fever except where it is a malignant fever (see malignantFever below), which seems to be a distinct problem and has been given its own topic.
For references to ‘flushing’ or to ‘flushing heat’.
For people who are hot and cold by turns.
For explicit references in the question to malignant fever, in whatever language or abbreviated form: ‘malig. fever’, ‘febris malig.’, ‘feb malig’, etc.

For explicit references to ‘fits’ in the sense of a physical problem suffered by someone (for instance someone with epilepsy), though if the entry refers only to ‘epilepsia’, ‘morbus caducus’ or some similar term without mentioning fits, then only the topic fallingSickness should be used. This is not for the use of the word ‘fits’ meaning intermittent, as in ‘it cometh by fits’, and for references to ‘fits’ where the problem is clearly passions-related, fitsPassions should be used instead.

For explicit references to ‘convulsions’; if the entry refers only to ‘epilepsia’, ‘morbus caducus’ or uses some similar term without mentioning convulsions, then only the topic fallingSickness should be used. Where the word ‘fits’ is used in this sense, the topic fits should be employed instead.
For explicit references to people foaming at the mouth. If the mouth is explicitly mentioned in the question then the topic throatMouth should also be supplied.
Specifically for explicit references to being ‘gnawed’ or complaints of a ‘gnawing’.
Specifically for explicit references to ‘griping’.

Specifically for explicit references to the sensation of being ‘pinched’. Where the reference is to someone being ‘fairy-pinched’ (a situation characterised by the appearance of unexplained marks on the body) the topic fairyPinched should be used instead.

It is occasionally possible for people to have stitches in places other than their sides, so if a part of the body is specified in the entry it should always be recorded with the relevant topic (it will usually be sides).
To be used when precisely this phrase is employed in a question.
Note that ‘pilling’ of hair means hair loss.
Note that hearing is a more general topic for use when an entry refers to hearing problems other than or short of outright deafness.
This is for problems with hearing other than outright deafness, for which the topic deafness should be used, or ringing in the ears, which is covered by the topic tinnitus.
Sometimes referred to in Latin by the word ‘tinnitus’, but also covering references to noises or bells ringing in the ears, ringing in the head, etc.
For all mentions of fistula except for fistula of the eye, which is aegilops.
Sometimes with the word ‘haemorrhoids’, sometimes ‘piles’ or ‘bleeding piles’; note that we have one case in which it affects the vulva rather than the anus.
This appears in entries as ‘hickets’ or the rather wonderful ‘hitchcocks’.

The expressions ‘impotentia coeundi’, ‘impotens sine erectione’ and ‘non sentit erectionem virgæ’, and a reference in English to someone who ‘wanteth virility & erection’, have all been encountered so far
Cannot turn in bed.
The phrase typically used for this is ‘cannot go’.

This is disability of a limb through injury or defect; it can affect parts other than the legs, so if the part of the body is specified in the question it should always be included as a topic. If someone is ‘lame in his legs’ he should be given the topics lameness and legs. Note that this topic should only be recorded when the word ‘lame’ is actually present in the question; if an entry simply specifies that someone cannot use a particular part of the body then the topic noUseOfPart should be used instead.

This is for entries in which someone is described as having no use of, or lost the use of, some part of their body, or in which it is noted that people ‘cannot stir’. Note that explicit references to palsy or paralysis should be given the topic palsy, and explicit references to lameness should be given the topic lameness. If someone is described as ‘lame in her arm’ and having ‘lost the use of her arm’ in the same entry, then the topics lameness, noUseOfPart and arms should all be used. There will probably be significant overlap between this topic and lameness, and possibly palsy.
‘benumbed’, etc.

Including all references to palsy or palsied limbs, as well as explicit uses of the term paralysis, which Napier uses as a synonym (or the Latin form) of palsy, in all of its senses. Also including cramps of limbs. Note that descriptions of people having lost the use of some part or parts of their body should instead be given the topic noUseOfPart.
Typically written in entries as ‘biles’ or ‘byles’.
Also written as ‘apostume’ or ‘apostema’.
Forman at least seems to have counted this as a problem that it was possible to suffer in particular parts of the body: leprosy in the head, for instance.
As in a sore, not as in painful; the Latin is ulcus, ulceris.
We may in the end want to differentiate the two.
Phlegm mentioned specifically in connection with vomiting or the stomach.
Used quite frequently by Napier as a symptom of mental disturbance or distress.

The entries for which this topic has been used all include variations on the phrase ‘goeth’ (or ‘walketh’) ‘up and down’. The significance of this is not yet clear. If it really is a sign of distress then we will probably need to move this topic under ‘passions’, but to date none of the entries in which the phrase has been seen has had any other suggestion of a passions-related problem.

Either in general, perhaps, or in combination with a particular part or parts of the body. This covers the terms ‘ache’ and ‘sore’ as well as ‘pain’ itself — though note that ‘sore’ can mean very or badly (as in ‘sore troubled’), and that references to a sore (noun rather than adjective) should be given the topic sore. The term ‘chiragra’ refers specifically to pain in the hand and should be given the topics pain and hands.
For this specific term; we may eventually unite this with shortWinded, once we are sure that they mean the same thing.

Coughing phlegm, phlegm on the chest, and simple references to ‘phlegm’, which (in absence of remarks about vomiting, the stomach or voiding) is assumed to be a chest/respiratory problem. Note that ‘saucefleme’ (or ‘salt fleme’ or ‘salt fleume’) is a swelling of the face supposedly caused by salty phlegm (references are also made to people having ‘saucy’ or ‘sawcy’ faces), and should be given the topics swelling and face but no phlegm-related topic.
The Oxford English Dictionary says this is ‘a medical condition characterized by difficulty in breathing or a choking sensation’.

Both as the phrase ‘short winded’ itself, and as descriptions of the form ‘cannot take her wind’ and the like; ‘ready to stop his/her wind’ is going down as readyToStopWind until we determine for sure that it means the same thing as this.
Whatever precisely this means, it affects chests and lungs.
This comes up alongside ‘sounding’ in one entry.
Now more commonly known as palpitations.

This has appeared twice in the Latin phrase ‘cordis palpitatio’, and far more often in English expressions such as ‘panting of the heart’, ‘trembling of the heart’ and ‘quivering at heart’. The topic heart should be supplied alongside this one if the heart is explicitly mentioned in the question.
‘pisseth blood’.
This seems to be what ‘diabetica passio’ means, though if that is the only term Napier ever uses then perhaps that should be the topic name. We are using this for now for clarity.
Inability to urinate.
At least for now, the topic ‘pain’ should not be used alongside this topic, unless the question mentions pain separately or in relation to a different body part or symptom.
This includes cases in which people fear a consumption.
As in appearance.
In Latin, Napier uses the term ‘ventus’ for wind; flatus is categorised separately.
This includes references in Latin to ascarides, and people who fear worms (or ‘metuit ascarides’).

Questions in which people are described as being involved with or speaking of Satan. This is distinct from people being tempted by Satan (to commit suicide or some other sin), which comes under ‘tempted and suicidal’ in the Diseases of the Mind category.

Questions in which people are described as being involved with or speaking of Satan. This is distinct from people being tempted by Satan (to commit suicide or some other sin), which should be given the topic temptedAndSuicidal. This topic can be inferred based on remarks in the judgment (if it is, evidence should be supplied).
Normally but not exclusively of children: suffering unexplained superficial injuries imputed to the influence of malign spirits. The term ‘fairy blasted’ is sometimes also used.

This topic can be inferred based on remarks in the judgment (if it is, evidence should be supplied). If a question is referring simply to someone experiencing the sensation of being ‘pinched’, however, the topic pinched should be used instead.
Seeing or hearing ghosts or spirits.

Note that questions about possession come under the topic witchcraft; if the issue is someone’s obsession with or involvement with the devil, then the topic devil should be used, and if the entry specifies that someone is ‘tempted by the devil’ then the topic should be temptedAndSuicidal. The topic haunted can be inferred based on remarks in the judgment (if it is, evidence should be supplied).

Questions about problems whose nature is described as ‘strange’; patients in these cases are most often described as ‘strangely taken’ or ‘strangely handled’. The strangeness of an illness was sometimes taken as an indication that it was the result of witchcraft.

The key word (or notion) is ‘strange’: any entry in which the question refers to someone being ‘strangely taken’, ‘strangely handled’, ‘vexed in a strange manner’, ‘strangely griped’, or uses any similar label. This topic should not be used for entries in which the expression is used in the judgment or event information.

Mental disorders whose nature is described as ‘strange’; patients in these cases are most often described as ‘strangely taken’ or ‘strangely handled’. The strangeness of an illness was sometimes taken as an indication that it was the result of witchcraft.

The key word (or notion) is ‘strange’: any entry in which the question refers to someone being ‘strangely taken’, ‘strangely handled’, ‘vexed in a strange manner’, ‘strangely griped’, or uses any similar label. This topic should not be used for entries in which the expression is used in the judgment or event information.

Supposedly preternatural attack or manipulation by a known or unknown person or agency. Unexplained conditions such as epilepsy were frequently believed or at least suspected to be the effects of witchcraft or demonic possession.

This topic is for entries recording a fear that someone’s ailment is due to bewitchment or being cursed. It can occasionally be used based on an explicit question in the question section; more commonly it is supplied (with evidence) based on remarks in the judgment. Sometimes the words ‘witch’ and ‘witchcraft’ are used, sometimes the reference is to someone being ‘beworded’ or ‘under an ill tongue’. Occasionally the only clue is that the names of suspected witches are included near or in amongst the judgment. As usual, the degree of confidence with which the topic is supplied should be recorded using cert. Most often in Napier the judgment includes the expression ‘metuit veneficium’ or a shortened form thereof. Any references to possession are to be given this topic for now, then we can revisit and check later on. The person believed to be a victim of witchcraft should be cb:subject in the entry, and should be included as usual within this topic; but the suspected witch should be recorded separately using the witchcraftSuspect topic. Sometimes witchcraft is suspected in general terms, and there is no mention of an individual believed to be responsible; if that is the case, the victim alone goes into cb:topic. Note that while possession comes under this heading, haunting is a separate topic, and also note that for references to people who are ‘strangely handled’, ‘strangely sick’, ‘taken in strange manner’ etc. we have the topics strangeAffliction and strangeAfflictionPassions.
Questions about the outcome of a pregnancy.

This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks made in the judgment. It is worth being careful of the difference between this topic and pregnancy, which is chiefly for questions about whether someone is pregnant. If a question is about childbirth and is medical (for instance, concerning a medical problem being suffered by a woman in the process of giving birth) then the medical topic childbirthMedical should be used instead.
Questions about the possibility of someone begetting or bearing children (or any more children).
This topic can be inferred based on remarks made in the judgment.
Questions about the sexual fidelity (past, present or future) of spouses or other partners.

The parties involved in or suspected of the infidelity are included as persons but not the wronged husband/wife. This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.
Questions about the sex of an unborn child
This topic can be inferred based on untranscribed material (judgment and event information); if it is, evidence should be supplied.

Whether someone should or will marry a given person; whether he/she should or will marry at all; which of two or more potential spouses to choose, or whether an already contracted marriage will turn out well.
This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.
Questions about the prospects for an impending marriage, the reuniting of separated spouses, the behaviour of one spouse towards another, and so forth.
This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.
Issues of uncertain or disputed fatherhood.
Whether or not the person in question is pregnant.

This does not include: the question of whether she ever can or will become pregnant, which is classed under fertility; questions about the outcome of the pregnancy, which is childbirth; medical questions about an imminent birth, which is chilbirthMedical; or questions about the sex of the unborn child, which is girlOrBoy. This topic can be inferred on the basis of comments in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and ‘future event information’), though it should be borne in mind that Napier was preoccupied with his female patients’ reproduction even where this was plainly not the problem at issue, so remarks such as ‘credo esse gravidam’ or ‘she was with child’ should not be taken as cast-iron proof that the querent asked about pregnancy.
Anything (other than prospective marriage) concerning actual or prospective amatory and/or sexual relations between unmarried couples.
This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.
The advisability of particular courses of action connected with the bringing up of children (e.g. fostering, nursing, becoming godparent).
Questions about the whereabouts and/or wellbeing of people absent from the querent for whatever reason.

This topic can if necessary be inferred on the basis of remarks in the judgment: typical judgments for absentPerson entries give suggested whereabouts for the missing party or a time when he or she is likely to return. Unless there is a strong reason to encode things differently, the absent person should be made the object (with the person asking being both querent and subject), and only the absent person should be included as a child of cb:topic. The person enquired about should be made cb:object, with the client as both cb:querent and cb:subject.
Whether someone is alive or dead at the time of asking. This is normally a subcategory of ‘absent person’ but sometimes refers to people whose whereabouts are known but whose condition is not.

Whether someone is alive or dead at the time of asking. If, as is usually the case, that person is absent or their whereabouts is unknown, then it should be accompanied by the topic absentPerson; the question is occasionally asked of people whose whereabouts are known but whose condition is not, in which case absentPerson should not be used. This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks made in the judgment. The person enquired about should be made cb:object, with the client as both cb:querent and cb:subject.
Questions about someone’s progress in the art of transmutation; propitious times for alchemical undertakings; or the veracity of other people’s claims to alchemical prowess.

Another category peculiar to the early days of Napier’s practice, in which he appears to have tested his astrological skills by reading the stars to divine what someone (occasionally himself) was thinking about at a given moment.

These questions concern the creation of ‘laminæ’ or ‘sigils’: rings, bracelets and the like marked with magical signs and produced under highly specified conditions. These objects were used to conjure or repel spirits, influence future events, or draw astral properties into the body.

Questions concerning the creation of ‘laminæ’ or ‘sigils’: rings, bracelets and the like marked with magical signs and produced under highly specified conditions. They are usually either interrogations about sigils that already have been made or elections about sigils that have yet to be made.
Questions posed by the practitioner about whether or not to help someone, medically or otherwise.
Along the lines of treatment but for non-medical questions.

A very few entries appear to constitute queries by the practitioner about the advisability of preparing or dispensing medicine at all at a given time. Such questions have not been categorised as ‘medical’ since no specific patient or medical issue is involved.
Entries in which the point at issue is someone’s character or personal qualities.
This topic can be inferred based on remarks made in the judgment or event information (if it is, evidence should be supplied).

These questions are all put by Napier, and are his attempts to ascertain whether or not a given person is guilty of some crime of which he or she has been accused but professes him or herself innocent.

Often the person in question comes to Napier specifically to say that he or she is not guilty, in which case the entry is likely an interrogation. The person whose innocence or guilt is at issue should be the object in the consultation, not the subject; the person ascertaining their guilt or innocence (often Napier himself) should be both querent and subject.

Disputes of any sort that do not clearly fall within the rubric of ‘legal matters’. This can cover anything from good-natured disagreements between friends to fisticuffs. This topic can be inferred based on remarks made in the judgment or event information (if it is, evidence should be supplied).

Questions about whether it is advisable to remain someone’s friend, whether someone will remain a friend, or about finding and making friends. There is an obvious overlap here with ‘marital prospects’ and ‘romantic relations’ questions, but where such relationships are not explicitly described as marital, romantic and/or sexual, they have been subsumed into this category.

Questions about whether it is advisable to remain someone’s friend, or whether someone will remain a friend. There is an obvious overlap here with maritalProspects and romanticRelations, but where such relationships are not explicitly described as marital, romantic and/or sexual, they should be given this topic.
Questions about whether or not a given rumour (usually involving the querent’s partner or associate) is true, or reports that a given rumour has been confirmed or refuted

Questions about whether the querent has secret enemies lying in wait for him or her. In some cases the enemies in question are not in fact very ‘secret’, being explicitly named in the consultation, but the term has been adopted since it is one that Forman uses himself in his Astrologicalle Judgmentes (where he spells it ‘secrete enimies’).
The person whose secret enemies are under discussion goes into the topic; on the few occasions when some candidate secret enemies are proposed, they can also be included.
Whether or not a given person is to be trusted, either in general or some particular matter.
Forman’s idiosyncratic Latin term for impending trouble of a non-medical nature.
A question, explicit or implicit, about whether particular people are guilty of witchcraft.

This topic can occasionally be used based on an explicit question in the question section; more commonly it is supplied (with evidence) based on remarks in the judgment. Sometimes the words ‘witch’ and ‘witchcraft’ are used, sometimes the reference is to someone being ‘beworded’ or ‘under an ill tongue’. Occasionally the only clue is that the names of suspected witches are included near or in amongst the judgment. As usual, the degree of confidence with which the topic is supplied should be recorded using cert. Most often in Napier the judgment includes the expression ‘metuit veneficium’ or a shortened form thereof. The suspected witch or witches should typically be cb:object, and they alone should be included within this topic. Sometimes witchcraft is suspected in general terms, and there is no mention of an individual believed to be responsible; if that is the case, this topic should not be employed at all. Conversely, on rare occasions there is a question about a suspected witch (typically in a clearingName entry) where no victim is specified; in that case, this topic should be employed but not witchcraftSufferedMedical or witchcraftSufferedNonMedical.
A few consultations (usually by ship owners) concern the welfare or whereabouts of a ship as such, rather than any of the people on board it.

The ship is listed in listPerson as org type="ship", and treated in the encoding just as an absent person would be - typically by being made object and being included (as an org) within cb:topic. This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied. The ship enquired about should be made cb:object, with the client as both cb:querent and cb:subject.
Which of two or more applicants to employ, or whether or not to employ a given applicant.

The person or persons under consideration as employee are included within the topic (all coded as cb:object), but not the prospective employer (who should be cb:subject). This topic can be inferred based on remarks made in the judgment or event information (if it is, evidence should be supplied).
Whether or not to take someone on as a student.

The person or persons under consideration as student are included within the topic (all coded as cb:object), but not the prospective teacher (who should be cb:subject). This topic can be inferred based on remarks made in the judgment or event information (if it is, evidence should be supplied).
Financial matters generally, including debts, wills, or the buying and selling of houses.
This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.
Questions concerning lawsuits or mentioning the actual or prospective intervention of legal authorities.
This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.
Should the client remain in or change her or his current employment?
This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.
Questions relating to a priest’s duties.
This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.
Gaining an advantage of some sort from an authority figure. This covers promotion, job offers, intervention in legal cases, and favours of any kind.
This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.
Questions about the likelihood of someone’s being sent to, or released from, prison.
This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.
Diary notes recording episodes in which Napier punishes a servant.

Written out in full, a typical entry would read (along with the time and date) ‘Iacobus flagellatus’ or something similar, but typically this is abbreviated to ‘Iac flag’, ‘I fl.’, or ‘I f’ and even ‘f I’, which are almost completely unintelligible to the uninitiated. In one or two places Napier himself takes responsibility (‘R N I fl.’ or similar). We have also encountered ‘Iac punitus sev.’ (punished severely), ‘Cast I’ (from ‘castigo’, chastise), and one diary note in which a Greek term also meaning chastise was used (‘παιδευθεις I’). The person in question should be added to listPerson, with the forename J if that is all that appears in the entry, or James if the entry has ‘Iac’ (or more). We have not yet established for certain whether the person in question is called Jacob or James (which is rendered Iacobus in Latin), but for now, consistency will help at the name-list editing stage.

Questions about whether and/or when it would be advisable to embark on a journey, or whether a proposed journey will be successful or profitable, or diary notes or questions about journeys that have alraedy taken place.
This topic can be inferred based on untranscribed material (judgment and event information); if it is, evidence should be supplied.
Whether or not someone should, or will have to, move house.
This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.
Whether a particular location is unlucky or unhealthy for the patient.

Where a particular problem is mentioned as being associated with the place, such as a sort of illness or a problem with money or fertility, the relevant topic(s) for that problem should be supplied too.
Questions about a person’s luck, including worries about misfortunes.

This topic should only be used where a question explicitly concerns itself with luck or fortune; where an entry is simply about the future, or what is likely to happen next, then the topic generalFuture should be employed instead.
In the early days of his practice, Napier quite regularly drew up astrological charts to find out why he had won or (more often) lost at cards, dice or other games.
Questions about someone’s present or future prosperity and/or social standing.
This is specifically employed for entries in which the term ‘state’ is used (in a non-medical sense), and takes resp.
Entries in which the person being asked about is known to be dead. It is seldom clear precisely what the question is in such entries, but in most cases cause of death seems the likeliest possibility.
These are typically interrogations or diary entries recording the time of someone’s death and/or burial, though we have encountered at least one horary question about the cause of someone’s death.
Past events in the personal life of the individual being asked about.

On occasion a question explicitly addresses a person’s history, but sometimes this topic is inferred in nativities for people who are already dead (since their fortune is clearly not at issue). Where the topic has been inferred, on these grounds or on the basis of remarks made in the judgment, evidence should be supplied.
Questions about what will happen next, or what the future holds.

Questions resembling the typical Forman ‘quid inde’ (what next) belong in this category; any general enquiries about what the future holds. Nativities should be given this topic, with an evidence value of inferred, unless there is evidence to indicate a more specific concern. Where an entry refers specifically to whether someone can expect good (or bad) fortune, then the topic fortune should be used instead.
Distinct from ‘life or death’ questions in that the person in question is not expected to die imminently.
Distinct from liveOrDie and liveOrDieMedical questions in that the person in question is not expected to die imminently.
Normally associated with a medical question, but sometimes relating to someone whose imminent death through non-medical causes (e.g. shipwreck or murder) is considered a possibility.

This topic covers questions relating to someone whose imminent death through non-medical causes (e.g. shipwreck or murder) is considered a possibility. If there is evidence that the question is medical then it should be given the topic liveOrDieMedical instead. This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks made in the judgment.
Which of two or more people will die first. A question most often posed by disgruntled spouses or people with an eye to an inheritance.
This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.

Questions explicitly noted as having been inspired by a (prophetic) dream. In Forman’s case, such dreams are usually his own, but he sometimes took clients’ dreams into account when assessing their cases. This is a category Napier uses only very rarely.
This topic does not cover entries in which people are described as suffering from dreams, or having bad dreams; in those instances the topic badDreams should be used instead.

Diary entries in which Napier records his own (often quite extreme) mood swings, accompanied by a star-chart. Where his elation or distress is explicitly ascribed to a religious experience or the failure of one to occur, these are categorised as ‘religious experience’ (q.v.), but records of his emotional state without any such explanation are placed under this heading.

Diary entries (entries tagged catRef target="#diary"/) in which Napier records his own (often quite extreme) mood swings, accompanied by a star-chart. Where his elation or distress is explicitly ascribed to a religious experience or the failure of one to occur, these are categorised as religiousExperience, but records of his emotional state without any such explanation should be recorded as emotions.

Napier regularly made cryptic and often emotionally intense notes, almost invariably in Latin, about having experienced divine grace at particular moments - or, conversely, about not having experienced it at particular moments when he had hoped or expected to. Many of these records are accompanied by star-charts, but what he hoped to learn from them remains decidedly opaque.
The typical formula runs ‘R. N. bene devotiss. affectus’. These are diary entries, so if there is no chart they should be added to the relevant Untranscribed Napier page instead.

Questions about whether and/or when it would be propitious to discuss a topic with someone, or diary notes or questions about conversations that have already taken place where the conversation itself is the significant point, rather than the subject discussed.
This topic can be inferred based on remarks made in the judgment or event information (if it is, evidence should be supplied).
Questions about encounters that have taken place.
Both parties in the encounter are included as persons.
Entries peculiar to Napier in which an astrological chart is accompanied solely by a report of someone’s having given him a present. It is far from clear exactly what he was trying to establish.

Questions about gifts. The majority of these are entries peculiar to Napier in which an astrological chart is accompanied solely by a report of someone’s having given him a present. It is far from clear exactly what he was trying to establish.
Diary entries in which Napier records having debated points of theology with acquaintances, where these are accompanied by a star-chart.
Whether and/or when it would be advisable to write or send a letter, on whatever subject.
Also for diary entries about receiving, reading or sending letters, in which the content of those letters is unstated or opaque.
Whether or not the querent should issue or respond to a summons (of either a legal or personal nature).
Whether the querent would be well advised to pay a visit or is likely to receive one, or questions about visits that have already taken place.
Both visitor and visitee are included as persons.
These are usually questions about the cause of the problem (witchcraft or foul play?) rather than requests for the animal(s) to be treated.
This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.
Questions about the location of missing possessions and the likelihood of their recovery, or the identity and whereabouts of thieves.

The person who has lost the item goes inside cb:topic - usually the entry’s subject - and if the suspected parties are specified, they (as objects) go in too. This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.
Entries in which the querent is recorded as having asked for advice or counsel of a non-medical nature.

Note that this is for non-medical entries in which Napier explicitly records a statement such as ‘X sent for my counsell’, and where the word ‘counsel’ (or a synonym) is explicitly used. This is not intended as a catch-all topic for all non-medical questions questions; non-medical questions that are difficult to categorise should be given the closest available topic, or unknown, and a TODO comment tag added recording the problem. An entry that uses the word ‘counsel’ or a synonym should be given this topic unless there is evidence that the question was medical, in which case medicalCounsel should be used instead.
Questions about the whereabouts and current doings of a given person, almost invariably one in whom the querent has a romantic and/or sexual interest.
This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.
Questions about the existence and/or whereabouts of hidden treasure.
This topic can be inferred on the basis of remarks in the untranscribed portion of the entry (judgment and event information); if it is, an appropriate evidence value should be supplied.

Supposedly preternatural attack or manipulation by a known or unknown person or agency, causing non-medical problems. Unexplained events such as sleepwalking or the sudden death of animals, were frequently believed or at least suspected to be the effects of witchcraft or demonic possession.

This topic is for entries recording a fear that someone’s non-medical problems are due to bewitchment or a curse. (The nature of those problems, if they are explained, can be recorded using other topics; animalDeathAndDisease is one typical such topic.) It can occasionally be used based on an explicit question in the question section; more commonly it is supplied (with evidence) based on remarks in the judgment. Sometimes the words ‘witch’ and ‘witchcraft’ are used, sometimes the reference is to someone being ‘beworded’ or ‘under an ill tongue’. Occasionally the only clue is that the names of suspected witches are included near or in amongst the judgment. As usual, the degree of confidence with which the topic is supplied should be recorded using cert. Most often in Napier the judgment includes the expression ‘metuit veneficium’ or a shortened form thereof. Any references to possession are to be given this topic for now, then we can revisit and check later on. The person believed to be a victim of witchcraft should be cb:subject in the entry, and should be included as usual within this topic; but the suspected witch should be recorded separately using the witchcraftSuspect topic. Sometimes witchcraft is suspected in general terms, and there is no mention of an individual believed to be responsible; if that is the case, the victim alone goes into cb:topic.
Questions put (normally by the practitioner himself) about contemporary events, e.g. whether Spain is likely to invade England this year.
Diary entries by Napier in which an account of the day’s weather is accompanied by a star-chart.

There are three reasons for the topic of a consultation to be classified as ‘unknown’. The relevant information may be lost through deletion or manuscript damage; there may have been no relevant information in the first place, or it may be stated in such cryptic terms that no one (yet) has managed to interpret it.

This should be given the attribute reason, specifying why the topic is not known; this takes the values deleted (the relevant information has been lost through deletion), msDamage (the relevant information has been lost through manuscript damage), notGiven (there was no relevant information in the first place) or notUnderstood (it has been stated in such cryptic terms that no one (yet) has managed to interpret it).
